greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) = one more than the number of iterations of A005361 needed to reach 1 from the starting value n.
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
Index entries for sequences computed from exponents in factorization of n
example: For n = 2 = 2^1, A005361(2) = 1, so we reach 1 in one step, and thus a(2) = 1+1 = 2.
For n = 4 = 2^2, A005361(4) = 2; A005361(2) = 1, so we reach 1 in two steps, and thus a(4) = 2+1 = 3.
For n = 6 = 2^1 * 3^1, A005361(6) = 1*1 = 1, so we reach 1 in one step, and thus a(6) = 1+1 = 2.
mathematica: ffi[x_] := Flatten[FactorInteger[x]] lf[x_] := Length[FactorInteger[x]] ep[x_] := Table[Part[ffi[x], 2*w], {w, 1, lf[x]}] expr[x_] := Apply[Times, ep[x]] Table[Length[FixedPointList[expr, w]]-1, {w, 2, 128}]
Table[Length@ NestWhileList[Apply[Times, FactorInteger[#][[All, -1]]] &, n, # != 1 &], {n, 105}] (* _Michael De Vlieger_, Jul 29 2017 *)
program: A005361(n) = factorback(factor(n)[, 2]); \\ This function from _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Nov 07 2014
(PARI) first(n) = my(v = vector(n)); v[1] = 1; for(i=2, n, v[i] = v[factorback(factor(i)[, 2])] + 1); v \\ _David A. Corneth_, Jul 28 2017
(Scheme) (define (A082091 n) (if (= 1 n) n (+ 1 (A082091 (A005361 n))))) ;; _Antti Karttunen_, Jul 28 2017
results.author: _Labos Elemer_, Apr 09 2003
ext: Term a(1)=1 prepended, Name and Example sections edited by _Antti Karttunen_, Jul 28 2017
